awd_titl_txt: UNS:  Synthesis and Dynamics of Elastic Capsules with Controlled Interfacial Elasticity
awd_abstract_narration:
CBET - 1511016
PI: Shelley L. Anna

Capsules are liquid drops or bubbles that have molecules or nanoparticles adsorbed onto their outer surfaces, which gives them unique mechanical properties.  Capsules are used in a variety of products including drug delivery formulations, cosmetics, paints, inks, and foodstuffs.  This project will investigate how the distribution of nanoparticles on the surface of a capsule affects the elasticity of the capsule interface and the deformation of the capsule as a whole under precisely controlled conditions.  The results of the study will provide scientists and engineers with information that will help them optimize capsule formulations for use in a wide array of specialized products.  Results from the project will also be used to develop educational modules to engage K-12 students and course content for university undergraduate and graduate students.
 
A microfluidic device will be used to adsorb a cationic surfactant-nanoparticle complex onto the interface of a gaseous bubble as it translates along a microchannel.  The goal of the experiment is to show how the properties of the capsule interface, especially its elasticity, are affected by the concentration of adsorbed nanoparticle complexes and their spatial distribution along the bubble surface, which will be determined using methods such as electron microscopy.  Dynamical properties of the capsule interfaces will be investigated using a microtensiometer developed at Carnegie Mellon University.  The microtensiometer will be used to measure interfacial tension and interfacial elasticity of the capsule and correlate it with interfacial coverage of the surfactant-nanoparticle complexes.  Finally, scale-up of capsule production to obtain a sufficient number of capsules for rheological measurements of capsule suspensions will be investigated by using parallel microfluidic channels and complex microfluidic circuits.  The results of the studies will be disseminated directly to industrial counterparts through workshops and short courses organized at Carnegie Mellon University.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this work was to explore ways to synthesize capsules, which are micrometer-sized liquid drops or bubbles covered in an elastic shell of nanometer-sized particles, for a wide range of therapeutic and commercial applications. Capsules have unique mechanical properties. They can control the release of specific substances, making them particularly useful in a variety of products such as drug delivery formulations, waste-water treatment approaches, and personal care products like cosmetics, paints and inks. Structurally, capsules have a strong rigid shell, made up of molecules and nanoparticles adsorbed onto their outer surface. This project explored how the nanoparticles move around and interact with each other on the surface of the capsule during and after its formation.

 

We conducted three types of experiments to elucidate the factors controlling capsule formation. First, we generated bubbles in different surfactant and particle mixtures, and varied the bubble size and speed. We imaged the bubble shape during this flow, allowing us to see how the bubble interface changes during the flow process. We also imaged the capsules that were formed and observed how the capsule shape and stability depends on the mixture composition and flow paramters. We also leveraged a related collaboration to use x-ray measurements to probe the structure and dynamics of particles adsorbed at a bubble interface. The intellectual merit of these experiments is that they have allowed us to connect nanoscale interfacial structure with interfacial mechanics and overall bubble stability.

The outcomes of the work conducted with the support of this grant are as follows:

(1)  A measurement apparatus and analysis method were developed and refined to permit observation of individual flowing bubbles confined in a capillary tube through surfactant-nanoparticle mixtures in which surface-active complexes are formed.

(2)  The flow of individual bubbles revealed that confined bubble shapes in a surface-active particle suspension are distinctly different from those found for bubbles in Newtonian fluids or simple surfactant solutions. These observations point to the non-uniform accumulation of material along the bubble due to the flow around the bubble, and in some conditions the removal of adsorbed material from the trailing end of the bubble.

(3)  Emerging bubbles were examined to find the conditions at which stable capsules formed. In conditions permitting adsorbed material to accumulate on the interface, highly non-spherical capsules can be formed that hold their shape. When material is shed from the interface, capsules are not as stable and return to spherical bubble shapes more quickly.

(4)  We also developed a continuous bubble production method that allows for the sustained production of uniform spherical or non-spherical capsules. The work on single bubble/capsule formation informs the design of an effective continuous capsule production method.

(5)  A microtensiometer assembled specially to work inline with an x-ray synchrotron light source was developed as part of a related collaboration. Preliminary work on this assembly has shown that surface tension can be measured accurately alongside small-angle x-ray scattering and x-ray photon correlation spectroscopy at the interface. For bubble interfaces exposed to a surface-active particle suspension, SAXS scattering profiles revealed nanoparticles adsorbed at the interface, and XCPS measurements indicated possible dynamic movements of these interfacially-adsorbed particles.

These methods taken together have the potential for broad technological impact by enabling the production of other complex surface active materials and connecting the characteristics of interfaces across multiple scales, from the nanoparticles to the nanoscale interfacial structure to the interfacial elasticity, to bubble and foam stability. These methods are independently valuable for broader characterization of transport and mechanics of complex mixtures of surface-active materials adsorbed at fluid interfaces. Additionally, the PI and her students participated in a range of education and outreach activities that provided additional broader educational impacts, including incorporating bubble flow into an undergraduate laboratory and describing surface phenomena in K-12 outreach activities.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 09/21/2021
Modified by: Shelley L Anna
